pullRequest.body:
From the Carleson project

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> List.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

### PR summary [f735871fba](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/20456/commits/f735871fbab43439f625a376e8427946e7bb4be0)

#### Import changes for modified files

No significant changes to the import graph


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|

</details>

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ AntitoneOn.integrableOn_isCompact`
`+ Integrable.mul_of_top_left`
`+ Integrable.mul_of_top_right`
`+ integral_le_sum_Ico_of_le`
`+ integral_le_sum_mul_Ico_of_antitone_monotone`
`+ integral_mono_on_of_le_Ioo`
`+ sum_Ico_le_integral_of_le`
`+ sum_mul_Ico_le_integral_of_monotone_antitone`
`- AntioneOn.integrableOn_isCompact`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

</details>

---

<details><summary>No changes to technical debt.</summary>

You can run this locally as
```
./scripts/technical-debt-metrics.sh pr_summary
```
* The `relative` value is the weighted *sum* of the differences with weight given by the *inverse* of the current value of the statistic.
* The `absolute` value is the `relative` value divided by the total sum of the inverses of the current values (i.e. the weighted *average* of the differences).
</details>

:v: sgouezel can now approve this pull request. To approve and merge a pull request, simply reply with `bors r+`. More detailed instructions are available [here](https://bors.tech/documentation/getting-started/#reviewing-pull-requests).

bors r+
Thanks for the review!

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/12752915130/job/35543384143)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/12752915130/job/35543383772)
Is there a reason `a` and `b` are naturals for your results, instead of integers?

It's just that most of the time sums are indexed by naturals. Results with integers would also make sense, but I think they would be used less often. For instance, in Carleson I need the Nat-indexed version.

Maybe it's useful to first do it for `Int` and then specialize to `Nat`? I'll let you decide.

bors d+
Given that a very large majority of the time sums are Nat-indexed, I'll keep the current version and leave the generalization to whoever needs it.

This proof part feels quite long. Should we have a version of [MeasureTheory.Memℒp.mul_of_top_left](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/MeasureTheory/Function/LpSeminorm/CompareExp.html#MeasureTheory.Mem%E2%84%92p.mul_of_top_left) for `IntegrableOn`?

I don't think it would make a difference: all the steps are pretty specific to the current situation, and the natural API lemmas are already there. The steps are:

* reduction from `Ico` to `Icc`
* argue that it suffices to show that the function is in L^\infty, because that implies L^1
* say that a product of L^\infty functions is in L^\infty
* say that a monotone function on a compact interval is in L^\infty, and that an antitone function on a compact interval is in L^\infty

For each step, we have an API lemma. The proof is a little bit longish because there are several atomic steps (and the proof of antitonicity has a `x - 1` in it so requires shifting the intervals). If you see missing API that would streamline this, I'll be happy to implement it!

You can remove step 2 if you add

* product of L^\infty and IntegrableOn is IntegrableOn
* monotone function on a compact interval is (L^p hence) IntegrableOn.

I'll let you decide whether you think this is worth implementing.

Good idea: no need to go through L^\infty, just argue that the product of an integrable function and an L^\infty function is integrable. And we already have almost everything for that, I just had to extend a little bit the API. It's clearly better now, thanks!

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat: Estimating a finite sum by an interval integral, for the product of a monotone and an antitone function
